attributes.title: The efficacy and safety of Banxia-Houpo-Tang for Chronic pharyngitis:Protocol for systematic review and meta-analysis
attributes.description: To establish a systematic and comprehensive approach for locate the evidence,a review and meta-analysis will be used to:Whether the Banxia-Houpo-Tang is effective or ease the pressure of antibiotic abusing in the treatment of pharyngitis.Risk assessment and identify the most promising measures.

attributes.title: Online Studies of Decision-Making in Healthy Aging
attributes.withdrawal_justification: edits to analysis plan prior to data collection and analysis

q1.value: A Timeline of Novelty in Romantic Relationships- Study 2

q3.value: Study 2 will determine at what stage in the relationship it is considered appropriate to incorporate novel behaviours, both sexual and nonsexual, into one's romantic relationship. Specifically, Study 2 will examine when novel behaviours (select based on the results of Study 1) are typically incorporated into romantic relationships for the first time. This study will aid in understanding how novelty typically develops and changes over the course of a relationship, and will be used to inform future research.

q4.value: As this is a descriptive study, we present no formal hypotheses.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a cross-sectional descriptive study of individuals in romantic relationships' experiences of novelty with their partner.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: The data is in the process of being collected via Amazon's Mechanical Turk (MTurk).

question.value: Participants will be recruited from Amazon's Mechanical Turk (MTurk), an online crowdsourcing platform that is commonly used for psychological research. An advertisement will be placed on the MTurk website for all MTurk users with active accounts to see, with information about the inclusion criteria as well as a link to the survey. Participants will be required to be at least 18 years of age, have an active MTurk account with at least 99% approval from previous experimenters in whose studies they have participated and at least 1000 completed HITs, live in the USA or Canada, be fluent in English, and be in a romantic relationship of at least 6 months. Eligible and interested participants will follow the link, and will be redirected to a survey hosted on Qualtrics, where the letter of information and consent will be presented. Informed consent will be received from each participant digitally (each participant must indicate they read the consent form and agree to take part before proceeding). Participants included in the final sample must correctly answer 2 attention checks and 1 captcha, in addition to meeting all inclusion criteria.

q14.value: As this is a descriptive study (and we therefore cannot conduct power analyses), we simply seek to gain a large enough sample to be considered moderately generalizable. We therefore seek to recruit approximately 500 participants per cell (500 responding to the novel sexual behaviours and 500 responding to the novel nonsexual behaviours).

question.value:
Participants will be asked to complete an online questionnaire that will assess their demographic information. Then, participants will be provided with a list of sexual or nonsexual behaviours (which list they see will be random) and asked to indicate which behaviours they have engaged in with their romantic partner before. Of the behaviours that they indicated they have engaged in with their partner before, they will be asked to indicate how long into their relationship they or their partner initiated this behaviour for the first time, and when it occurred most recently. For the behaviours participants indicated they have not engaged in with their current romantic partner before, they will be asked to indicate how long into a relationship it would be considered appropriate to introduce that behaviour for the first time.

Additionally, participants will be asked to respond to items regarding their responsiveness (Reis, Crasta, Rogge, Maniaci, & Carmichael, in press), sexual communal strength (Muise, Impett, Kogan, & Desmarais, 2012), relational boredom (Harasymchuk & Fehr, 2012), potential for self-expansion (Lewandowski & Ackerman, 2006), sexual satisfaction (Lawrence & Byers, 1998), and relationship satisfaction (Hendrick, 1988). In addition, attention checks and captchas will be included throughout to ensure participants were paying attention throughout the surveys and that they are not bots.

Responsiveness, sexual communal strength, relational boredom, potential for self-expansion, sexual satisfaction, and relationship satisfaction scores will be determined by calculating the average of the respective scale's items.

We will plot a timeline using the means and standard errors of the relationship length at which participants incorporated the various novel behaviours into their relationship for the first time. For comparison, we may also plot a timeline of when participants who have not engaged in the novel behaviour believe it would be appropriate to introduce into the relationship, and may compare values on the two timelines.

q22.value: Participants will be required to be at least 18 years of age, have an active MTurk account with at least 99% approval from previous experimenters in whose studies they have participated and at least 1000 completed HITs, live in the USA or Canada, be fluent in English, and be in a romantic relationship of at least 6 months. Participants included in the final sample must correctly answer 2 attention checks and 1 captcha, in addition to meeting all inclusion criteria. In addition, participants who are are deemed to be careless responders (example: indicating they were married before their relationship began with their partner) will be removed from the final sample.

In addition, participants who are are deemed to be careless responders (example: indicating they were married before their relationship began with their partner) will be removed from the final sample.

registration_responses.q1: A Timeline of Novelty in Romantic Relationships- Study 2
registration_responses.q3: Study 2 will determine at what stage in the relationship it is considered appropriate to incorporate novel behaviours, both sexual and nonsexual, into one's romantic relationship. Specifically, Study 2 will examine when novel behaviours (select based on the results of Study 1) are typically incorporated into romantic relationships for the first time. This study will aid in understanding how novelty typically develops and changes over the course of a relationship, and will be used to inform future research.
registration_responses.q4: As this is a descriptive study, we present no formal hypotheses.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to any human observation of the data
registration_responses.q11: The data is in the process of being collected via Amazon's Mechanical Turk (MTurk).
registration_responses.q14: As this is a descriptive study (and we therefore cannot conduct power analyses), we simply seek to gain a large enough sample to be considered moderately generalizable. We therefore seek to recruit approximately 500 participants per cell (500 responding to the novel sexual behaviours and 500 responding to the novel nonsexual behaviours).
registration_responses.q22: Participants will be required to be at least 18 years of age, have an active MTurk account with at least 99% approval from previous experimenters in whose studies they have participated and at least 1000 completed HITs, live in the USA or Canada, be fluent in English, and be in a romantic relationship of at least 6 months. Participants included in the final sample must correctly answer 2 attention checks and 1 captcha, in addition to meeting all inclusion criteria. In addition, participants who are are deemed to be careless responders (example: indicating they were married before their relationship began with their partner) will be removed from the final sample.
registration_responses.q8.question: This is a cross-sectional descriptive study of individuals in romantic relationships' experiences of novelty with their partner.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants will be recruited from Amazon's Mechanical Turk (MTurk), an online crowdsourcing platform that is commonly used for psychological research. An advertisement will be placed on the MTurk website for all MTurk users with active accounts to see, with information about the inclusion criteria as well as a link to the survey. Participants will be required to be at least 18 years of age, have an active MTurk account with at least 99% approval from previous experimenters in whose studies they have participated and at least 1000 completed HITs, live in the USA or Canada, be fluent in English, and be in a romantic relationship of at least 6 months. Eligible and interested participants will follow the link, and will be redirected to a survey hosted on Qualtrics, where the letter of information and consent will be presented. Informed consent will be received from each participant digitally (each participant must indicate they read the consent form and agree to take part before proceeding). Participants included in the final sample must correctly answer 2 attention checks and 1 captcha, in addition to meeting all inclusion criteria.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Participants will be asked to complete an online questionnaire that will assess their demographic information. Then, participants will be provided with a list of sexual or nonsexual behaviours (which list they see will be random) and asked to indicate which behaviours they have engaged in with their romantic partner before. Of the behaviours that they indicated they have engaged in with their partner before, they will be asked to indicate how long into their relationship they or their partner initiated this behaviour for the first time, and when it occurred most recently. For the behaviours participants indicated they have not engaged in with their current romantic partner before, they will be asked to indicate how long into a relationship it would be considered appropriate to introduce that behaviour for the first time.

Additionally, participants will be asked to respond to items regarding their responsiveness (Reis, Crasta, Rogge, Maniaci, & Carmichael, in press), sexual communal strength (Muise, Impett, Kogan, & Desmarais, 2012), relational boredom (Harasymchuk & Fehr, 2012), potential for self-expansion (Lewandowski & Ackerman, 2006), sexual satisfaction (Lawrence & Byers, 1998), and relationship satisfaction (Hendrick, 1988). In addition, attention checks and captchas will be included throughout to ensure participants were paying attention throughout the surveys and that they are not bots.
registration_responses.q18.question: Responsiveness, sexual communal strength, relational boredom, potential for self-expansion, sexual satisfaction, and relationship satisfaction scores will be determined by calculating the average of the respective scale's items.
registration_responses.q19.question: We will plot a timeline using the means and standard errors of the relationship length at which participants incorporated the various novel behaviours into their relationship for the first time. For comparison, we may also plot a timeline of when participants who have not engaged in the novel behaviour believe it would be appropriate to introduce into the relationship, and may compare values on the two timelines.

This study will aid in understanding how novelty typically develops and changes over the course of a relationship, and will be used to inform future research.

question.value:
Participants will be asked to complete an online questionnaire that will assess their demographic information. Then, participants will be provided with a list of sexual or nonsexual behaviours (which list they see will be random) and asked to indicate which behaviours they have engaged in with their romantic partner before. Of the behaviours that they indicated they have engaged in with their partner before, they will be asked to indicate how long into their relationship they or their partner initiated this behaviour for the first time, and when it occurred most recently. For the behaviours participants indicated they have not engaged in with their current romantic partner before, they will be asked to indicate how long into a relationship it would be considered appropriate to introduce that behaviour for the first time.

Additionally, participants will be asked to respond to items regarding their responsiveness (Reis, Crasta, Rogge, Maniaci, & Carmichael, in press), sexual communal strength (Muise, Impett, Kogan, & Desmarais, 2012), relational boredom (Harasymchuk & Fehr, 2012), potential for self-expansion (Lewandowski & Ackerman, 2006), sexual satisfaction (Lawrence & Byers, 1998), and relationship satisfaction (Hendrick, 1988). In addition, attention checks and captchas will be included throughout to ensure participants were paying attention throughout the surveys and that they are not bots.

Responsiveness, sexual communal strength, relational boredom, potential for self-expansion, sexual satisfaction, and relationship satisfaction scores will be determined by calculating the average of the respective scale's items.

We will plot a timeline using the means and standard errors of the relationship length at which participants incorporated the various novel behaviours into their relationship for the first time. For comparison, we may also plot a timeline of when participants who have not engaged in the novel behaviour believe it would be appropriate to introduce into the relationship, and may compare values on the two timelines.

attributes.title: Exploring the role of orthography in auditory word recognition

q1.value: Exploring the role of orthography in auditory word recognition

q3.value:
Research Questions
How does hearing a heterophonic homograph (different sound, same spelling) of a related word before hearing the target word affect lexical decision? As an example, could “bass” like the fish prime the target “guitar”? Is this effect comparable to the effect of hearing the correct associate (e.g. “bass” with a long ‘a’ sound)? Is the effect greater than the effect of hearing a phonological control word (e.g. “bus”)?

q4.value: If orthography mediates auditory word recognition, then lexical decision reaction times should be faster after both the correct associate and the homograph of the associate, as compared to an unrelated word or a phonological control (i.e. a word that sounds very similar to the correct associate).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The design is within-subjects. Subjects will complete 5 trials of each of the three different experimental conditions (correct associate + target, homograph of associate + target, phonological control + target) and the control condition (unrelated word + target), as well as an equal number of trials in which the target is replaced by a pseudoword. In total then, each participant will complete 40 trials.

q9.value: The trial type order will be randomized across subjects. Which type of prime is presented with which target will also be randomized.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
- Recruitment: Participants for the experiment will be recruited online via Prolific. They will be provided some monetary compensation (equivalent to at least $8 per hour) for their participation. 
- Inclusion/Exclusion rules: Participants must be at least 18 years old, be fluent in English, and list English as a first language, and report no hearing difficulties.
- Study timeline: Participants will be recruited and tested between March 6 and 31, 2020.

q13.value: The target sample size is 300 participants.

q14.value: A related study investigating semantic priming by homophones during visual lexical decision used 100 participants tested on 15 words per experimental condition. Since this experiment will use only 5 words per experimental condition, I wanted to have three times as many participants.

q15.value: Data collection will be terminated after the desired sample size has been achieved.

question.value:
All subjects will participate in three different experimental conditions: 1) correct associate followed by target, 2) homograph of associate followed by target, and 3) phonological control followed by target. Phonological controls will be real words created by changing a single phoneme in the correct associate.
A fourth (control) condition will use an unrelated word followed by the target. This unrelated word will share no phonemes with its corresponding correct associate and have approximately the same HAL (Hyperspace Analogue to Language) frequency.
In addition to these four trial types, there will also be an equal number of non-experimental trials in which the target is replaced by a pronounceable pseudoword.
Reaction time and accuracy will be recorded for each trial.
For each participant, the average reaction time in correct trials for each condition will be calculated. The grand average or mean of these averages will then be calculated for each condition.

I plan to conduct pairwise t-tests to compare reaction times in each of the four conditions (correct associate, homograph of associate, phonological control, unrelated word).  The correct associate and homograph are both expected to produce significantly faster reaction times than the unrelated word. Reactions times in the phonological control condition, however, are not expected to significantly differ from the unrelated word condition.
In addition to using frequentist statistics, I also plan to use Bayesian procedures to strengthen my analysis.

q21.value: The alpha level for frequentist tests will be 0.05.

q22.value: I will exclude all data from participants who report experiencing technical difficulties or who have lexical decision accuracies that are more than 2 standard deviations below average. I will also exclude data from trials with response times that are more than 2 standard deviations away from the participant’s mean. If a participant’s mean reaction time is more than 2 standard deviations away from the grand average, all of their data will be excluded.

q23.value: Trials with incomplete or missing data will be excluded.

Is the effect greater than the effect of hearing a phonological control word (e.g. “bus”)?

attributes.title: PRISMA-Checklist_03-06-20
attributes.description: Addendum to the Scoping Review Protocol

summary.value: Our scoping review has been written and peer-reviewed for publication. We are currently revising the manuscript and noticed the error in our checklist stating that we search the grey literature for abstracts/conference proceedings. We did not search the grey literature for these types of articles and we did not include these types of articles in our scoping review results.

registration_responses.summary: Our scoping review has been written and peer-reviewed for publication. We are currently revising the manuscript and noticed the error in our checklist stating that we search the grey literature for abstracts/conference proceedings. We did not search the grey literature for these types of articles and we did not include these types of articles in our scoping review results.

attributes.title: Raíssa Silva Souza
attributes.description: Segurança do enfermeiro no manejo da terapia antineoplásica: revisão do escopo Objetivo Identificar e sintetizar as evidências científicas sobre a segurança do enfermeiro do câncer no manejo da terapia antineoplásica. Formulação de Perguntas P (População) - Enfermagem Oncológica. C (Conceito) - Segurança do Trabalho. C (Contexto) - Antineoplásicos. A questão de pesquisa estabelecida foi: que evidência científica, no contexto de agentes antineoplásicos, está disponível para garantir a segurança ocupacional da enfermagem oncológica?

summary.value:
PROTOCOLO - SCOPING REVIEW
Nurse Safety in the Management of Antineoplastic Therapy: Scoping Review
Objetivo
Identify and synthesize the scientific evidence on cancer nurse safety in the management of antineoplastic therapy.
Question Formulation
P (Population)  – Oncology Nursing.
C (Concept) –  Occupational Safety. 
C (Context) – Antineoplastic Agents.
The established research question was: what scientific evidence, in the context of antineoplastic agents, is available to ensure the occupational safety of the oncology nursing?
Inclusion criteria
Will be included: research; published in full in english, spanish and portuguese; dealing with nurse safety in the management of antineoplastic therapy, without time limit.
Exclusion criteria
Will be excluded: editorials, experience reports, theoretical essays and studies that address only patient safety. 
Data collect
•	Search for similar scoping reviews

•	A preliminary search was performed on the databases: CINAHL, PubMed, Literatura Latino-americana e do Caribe em Ciências da Saúde (LILACS), SCOPUS, Web of Science e biblioteca Cochrane.

•	Identification of descriptors and keywords
An initial search was conducted on the PubMed and CINAHL portal to identify the main descriptors and keywords used in studies that address the topic of interest from the combination of MeSH identified for the research mneumonic: ("Antineoplastic Agents" [Mesh] OR "Drug Therapy" [Mesh] OR "Chemotherapy, Adjuvant" [Mesh] OR "Induction Chemotherapy" [Mesh] OR "Consolidation Chemotherapy" OR "Maintenance Chemotherapy" [Mesh] OR "Medication Therapy Management" [Mesh] OR "Administration and Dosage" [Mesh]) AND ("Oncology Nursing"[Mesh]  OR “Nursing"[Mesh])  AND ("Safety"[Mesh] OR "Safety Management"[Mesh] OR "United States Occupational Safety and Health Administration"[Mesh] OR "National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (U.S.)"[Mesh] OR "Equipment Safety"[Mesh] OR "Personal Protective Equipment"[Mesh])

data.name: Nurse Safety in the Management of Antineoplastic Therapy Scoping Review (1).docx
